unnormalised: Retail sales in India saw a significant uptick this Q3, climbing by 12.5% y-o-y, according to the Retailers Association of India (RAI). The growth is primarily attributed to the festive season, with Diwali sales contributing ~35% to the total. This festive surge is a stark contrast to the -2% decline observed in the same period last year, highlighting the resilience of the Indian consumer.
normalised: Retail sales in India saw a significant uptick this Q three, climbing by twelve point five percent year on year, according to the Retailers Association of India (R-A-I). The growth is primarily attributed to the festive season, with Diwali sales contributing approximately thirty five percent to the total. This festive surge is a stark contrast to the minus two percent decline observed in the same period last year, highlighting the resilience of the Indian consumer.

unnormalised: Apparel and accessories retailers reported a substantial surge, averaging 18% growth, while footwear chains experienced a rise of ~15%. Electronics stores also enjoyed a positive run, showing a 10% increase, fueled by the demand for new smartphones and smart home devices. Even grocery stores, a staple, saw a respectable 8% increment in sales.

unnormalised: However, the report also highlighted variations across different regions. South India led the pack with a 14% growth, closely followed by West India at ~13%. North India registered a 12% increase, while East India saw a more modest rise of 10%. This divergence underscores the impact of regional economic factors and consumer preferences.

unnormalised: Online retail platforms played a crucial role, accounting for approximately 25% of total retail sales during the festive season. E-commerce giants like Flipkart and Amazon reported a combined GMV of $9.2 billion, indicating a YoY growth of 20%. Notably, Tier II and Tier III cities contributed to over 60% of the total online sales, suggesting wider adoption of digital shopping.

Notably, Tier two and Tier three cities contributed to over sixty percent of the total online sales, suggesting wider adoption of digital shopping.

unnormalised: Several factors influenced this growth. Firstly, increased disposable income among middle-class households drove higher spending. Secondly, aggressive promotional campaigns and discounts by retailers attracted a large customer base. Thirdly, the easing of COVID-19 restrictions enabled a return to physical stores, further boosting sales. Lastly, the availability of easy financing options such as BNPL (Buy Now Pay Later) schemes encouraged impulse buying.

unnormalised: Looking ahead, the RAI projects a steady growth of 9% for the next fiscal year. This forecast assumes continued economic recovery, stable inflation rates, and favorable government policies. However, challenges remain, including rising input costs, supply chain disruptions, and potential fluctuations in consumer sentiment. Retailers are advised to focus on enhancing customer experience, optimizing supply chains, and embracing omnichannel strategies to sustain growth.
